In spite of that, Dogpatch knocks out the competition hands down. For pure bouldering, this is the place to be.My only negative feedback is that I wish they one in the South Bay as well.

A kids section, yes indeed, my oh my.  The kids section is a decent size with walls to climb, a castle and a curly slide.  My son played with other climber's boys, while I climbed on the rest of the walls.  This is a serious bouldering gym.  There are a variety of problems spread out on every wall so it seemed like one could climb anywhere and everywhere.  The walls are high,  15 to 20 feet. They did not feel too high when I was on easy problems, but they certainly did when I was on the harder grades.   I wonder what kind of insurance they have? It is a great addition to the city... a one of a kind place.

Third day trying out dogpatch, i regularly climb v4s.  The walls are too high. Its just plain unsafe to jump or fall from the top 5' so its impossible to attempt anything near your limits unless its near the bottom.  Tried several v3s to substitute, for some reason the routes are not labeled the same.  I could do most the v3s, but none were very fun or creative routes and it was impossible to enjoy being on edge about the height.  Kept looking down to see if it was safe to fall, no fun.  Wont be coming back, maybe that's what the upper level climbers want, as long as it doesn't tax the route setters from keeping up at the reg. Gym i don't care. Plus theres just as many screaming children but only a few climbers to drown them out, and the chick at the desk was playing an ozzy album the entire time, as if to enhance the cool factor but it just got old after the first song...

Used to regularly frequent Mission Cliffs for the bouldering. I haven't been there since Dogpatch Boulders opened up. This gym is huge and has a vast array of different climbing problems. It's clean and the routes get changed regularly.Parking is usually not a problem either right outside or around the back.
I could spend the rest of my life here. It's expensive, but it's the largest gym I've ever climbed in and the staff are super cool. I'll absolutely be coming back!
Great big bouldering gym with lots of problems to work on. I really like the variety of the routes. It is a really great place to spend the day.

This review is only for half a gym, as that was all that was open during the two member previews last week.High walls, great angles, well set problems, and top outs. This is as good as bouldering gets without being outside. When the gym opens, there should be over 300 problems set by the same crew that does all of the Touchstone routesetting. If you like bouldering at a Touchstone gym, you'll love bouldering here.One difference in the setting style here is the lack of a finishing designation at the top of the wall. Instead of a tape marking where to place your hand to finish the problem, it is expected that the climber just grab the top anywhere. Perhaps with the greater height, they didn't want to put riskier moves at the end.The walls are high. Taking a fall from 18 feet up can be a little hard to get used to. The 14 inches of foam with seamlessly stitched tarp over it lessens the blow enough to prevent injury, but it still isn't the most pleasant feeling.Besides the amazing terrain, what this gym has over all other Touchstone gyms is two sections with top-outs(!), a center arch (was sadly not climbable during the member preview), and a smaller back wall. Planet Granite just lost its big selling point for me.In my opinion this is the best climbing gym in the Bay Area. For roped climbing I'll obviously be sticking around Mission Cliffs, but Dogpatch is my new go to for bouldering.

Despite the slight omniscient smell of feet, I had a great time here. I attended an "Intro to Bouldering" class which will be as helpful as you make it and was impressed by the quality of the facilities and the amenities offered (treadmill, weights).

Awesome! Just awesome. When I heard they were opening up, I was skeptical. But they did it right! Huge gym! Open routes. And cool FRIENDLY staff. Great for beginners. You could do V0 for days. And yet they still have the super tricky thinky stuff. Top outs on a lot of routes makes this place just exciting! I'm fairly big on trad/lead. But this place is my new favorite. Hope it doesn't get overrun. Yea, on second thoughtI take it all back. It sucks. You guys stay home. :))

This place is AMAZING! It's like a giant playground for adults!!!!!! I was in complete amazement the first time I came in, and I loved it so much I HAD to get a membership. All the routes are up for a decent amount of time allowing you to learn them and knock them down, then before you know it they change it up to make it fun and exciting all over again. Love this place and would recommend anyone looking for a great climbing gym to come by.

Dogpatch is probably the best climbing gym I've been to: it's spacious and rarely crowded; the staff is knowledgeable; and the routes are varied and fun. There is so much variety, and there's never a worry about running out of things to climb. It's in the city, so was always a bit of a schlep for me, but always worth it. Dogpatch will always be the bouldering gym that I measure other gyms against. Unfortunately, I've yet to find one that measures up!

This is one of the best bouldering gyms I've been to. Love the open space, high ball problems and the friendly staff. The only downside is they never clean the floors! It's one of the most filthy gyms, my new pants had dirt (not just chalk) and my feet always turn brown. So gross! By the end of my climbing session I hate to put my dirty feet in my shoes because there is no where to clean them off, other than a shower. They should really take more pride in their space and clean the floors.
Large and spacious, friendly and fairly priced. Challenging for all levels.
This is the best bouldering gym I've ever seen. My only complaints would be that the weight room area is too small and that the locker rooms is lacking considering the place is so new.

The height here scares me, because I like to be in a harness.  Still, it's new and spacious, and if you prefer bouldering, I don't know of a better indoor option with higher walls.  There are no weights and no real "gym" area, only 4-6 ellipticals and tread mills near the entrance.  I've never had to wait for a machine though.  People are there to climb, and it can be very entertaining just to watch sometimes.
Boulder paradise. Clean, new, massive, uncrowded, challenging. Half block from post-climb ice cream. Can I give six stars?

paradise for the boulderer in a part of the city where parking is free and not terribly difficult. soo many different surface angles to choose from and the high topouts take some getting used to (i still freak out). it's spartan if you want to do anything other than boulder, but that suits me. it would be nice if the passes were a little cheaper, cos if it were i'd go more often.

Touchstone just gets it. A gym just dedicated to bouldering, pure and simple. The layout of the gym is just massive: Slab, Overhangs and straight-up face. The floor is nicely padded so falling off of a 20 ft problem isn't that imitating. A lot of the original crew of route setters have left and they are breaking in new setters. Overall, a great place to boulder.

I go to Touchstone's GWPC in Oakland most days but decided to stray away from the norm today. The setup of Dogpatch Boulders is great with many intriguing and challenging puzzles.  The space is massive and it's impossible to get bored from repitition due to so many route options.
This ain't your grandma's bouldering. Dogpatch offers the greatest indoor climbing experience you can get! So much variety - it kicks my ass every time! ...in a good way :)

Oh man, where do i start? This place is bomb diggity! Sweet staff, sweet routes, super sweet soft floor, they even have bathrooms installed now, oh and the space! There is so much space! Can't wait for the thing to be in full swing.

I came to this place because I was excited to see a gym exclusively devoted to bouldering. It lives up to the hype in that it is huge, has lots of options to top out, and as a beginner I was satisfied at the number of V0s and V1s. I only wish my fingers lasted longer! I didn't go for the 5th star though because it was a little dirty (my legs are covered in unidentified black stuff) and I didn't perceive a good gym culture that I look forward to.

This basically a grown up's playground. I love bouldering and this place is really nice since it doesn't have top-roping. There is a huge variety of climbing walls including a huge arch where you practice your overhanging skills. The day pass price is a bit steep, so make sure to come in with a friend who has a membership. The locker room can be a bit nicer, as it is kind of small and not as nice as PG's.

This is based on my first visit.  Signing in was easy, I got some loaner climbing shoes and chalk for no extra $.  This is bouldering like I've never seen before.  Huge, varied "cliffs".  Overhangs, corners, crevices and even a "natural bridge" type feature on the middle rock.  I spent a few hours and basically tried climbing all of the V0 difficulty routes I could find.  Even though these are the easiest routes, there was still a lot of variety and they were challenging for me.  I saw more experienced climbers performing feats of vertical movement that don't fit in with my understanding of gravity.  A day later, as I write this review, my aching muscles are telling me I got a good workout.  Can't wait to go back!

I'm a very occasional (read: maybe a few times a year a tops) / beginner climber but I will be going more often now that this gym has opened in my neighborhood. This review is for the beginners out there... Each visit is $20 and shoe rentals are $4. If you don't have a recent waiver on file, you'll need to do that and bring your ID. You're supposed to watch a video online, but other than that there's no test of anything. At Mission Cliffs, you have to know how to tie knots, secure your harness, belay people etc. Here, there are no harnesses. The walls are quite high IMHO so if you fall and don't fall properly, I could see it being a bit dangerous. I personally find it really fun though if you take your time and know your limits and don't push yourself into a situation you can't handle. It's also really interesting to watch other people "solve problems" and then trying to figure things out on your own as well. The levels go from V0-V8 with V0 being the easiest. However, I have found not all V0s are created equal... there are parts of the gym where you are meant to / or can climb on top of the structure and then take a ladder down. The staff is really nice (shout out to bernard who to took the time to give me some beginner tips) and welcoming.
